name: Yogyakarta
fun_fact: Fun fact: Yogyakarta is the only city in Indonesia still ruled by a Sultan! The current Sultan Hamengku Buwono X is also the provincial governor, and the royal palace (Keraton) built in 1755 remains a living palace where traditional Javanese ceremonies, gamelan music, and wayang puppet shows continue daily.

hero_dishes.name: Gudeg
hero_dishes.description: Yogyakarta's signature dish - young unripe jackfruit (gori) cooked slowly for hours with coconut milk and Javanese palm sugar until tender and sweet. The brown Javanese curry is served with rice, chicken, boiled duck egg, tofu, tempeh, and krecek (spicy cattle skin stew). It's distinctively sweet compared to other Indonesian dishes.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Gudeg has been Yogyakarta's soul food for generations, with recipes passed down through families since the Mataram Sultanate era. The slow-cooking process (often 4-6 hours) and sweet palm sugar flavor reflect Javanese patience and preference for subtle, sweet tastes.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gudeg Yu Djum (most famous, 7 locations, open since 1951 - known for being the sweetest version), Gudeg Pawon (traditional village-style kitchen, open only 3 hours at night, food served directly from hot pots), Gudeg Yu Narni (since 1996), and street stalls along Malioboro Street

hero_dishes.name: Sate Klathak
hero_dishes.description: Skewered grilled goat meat seasoned with unique spice blend, served with spicy sauce. Unlike typical Indonesian satay, the meat is grilled on iron skewers (not bamboo) over charcoal.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Javanese street food that showcases the local preference for goat meat and charcoal grilling techniques.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout Yogyakarta, especially near Malioboro Street and Pasar Beringharjo market

hero_dishes.name: Royal Palace Cuisine at Bale Raos
hero_dishes.description: Authentic dishes once reserved for the Sultan's table, including traditional Javanese delicacies prepared using centuries-old royal recipes. Features rare spice combinations and elaborate cooking techniques preserved by palace chefs.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Founded to preserve and share the unique culinary heritage of the Yogyakarta Palace (Keraton). These flavors were once only enjoyed by the Sultan and royal family.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bale Raos restaurant near Taman Sari Water Castle - the only restaurant in Yogyakarta specializing in authentic palace cuisine

signature_drinks.name: Es Dawet Ayu
signature_drinks.description: Traditional Javanese sweet drink with rice flour jelly (cendol), coconut milk, and palm sugar syrup served over shaved ice. Refreshing and cooling in tropical heat.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed throughout the day, especially in the afternoon heat. Found at Pasar Beringharjo market and street vendors.

signature_drinks.name: Wedang Ronde
signature_drinks.description: Hot ginger drink with glutinous rice balls filled with crushed peanuts and palm sugar. Warming and aromatic.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Traditional evening drink, especially popular during rainy season. Street vendors sell it from carts at night.

food_culture_notes: Food in Yogyakarta is remarkably affordable: street food costs IDR 10,000-20,000 (~$0.60-1.20 USD), mid-range meals IDR 50,000-100,000 (~$3-6 USD)
Malioboro Street is the culinary heartbeat - bustling with gudeg stalls, lumpia carts, and authentic Jogja street food at every corner
Pasar Beringharjo is one of the oldest markets in Jogja and a paradise for local food lovers, perfect for sampling traditional Javanese snacks
Javanese cuisine uses palm sugar extensively, giving many dishes a distinctive sweet flavor profile unlike other Indonesian regions
Street food culture is central - locals prefer eating at humble warungs and night stalls rather than fancy restaurants
Batik patterns and Javanese arts are deeply connected to food culture - traditional markets sell both textiles and street food side by side
